chats.Michelle Palys: Love to see female professors in the program, in particular in the Leadership subject. Also, I had never had a minority female professor with construction background as myself. I am a Latina by the way! Thank you for being yourselves. LOVE IT!

chats.Vikas Singh: I believe  there's a thin line on when to manage and when to lead.

chats.Kari Keating: @Michelle - Prof Loyd is an inspiration for sure. Glad you are here connecting with us.

chats.CA2: Zhandos Zhanserikov (eLearning): @Gregory, it will be available on our home page of Canvas under the “quick links” in the “Live Sessions and Office Hours” tab.

chats.LSN: Saumya 'Saum' Pallav (eLearning): Click on the pop-up to join the breakout rooms. Please let me know if you have any issues in joining. Thank you!

chats.Morgan Schwenn: this reminds me of the new Netflix documentary 14 peaks (really interesting from a leadership & teams point) & Awesome movie!

chats.Velineni Rao: Group 7 - Hierarchy is necessary evil, takes care of obstacles/hurdles for the team (provide cover from politics and noise so team can be successful)

chats.Kari Keating: I like how students are connecting this question to the content on Coursera about Decision Making.

chats.Elizabeth Luckman: “Necessary evil” - interesting choice of phrase to capture both costs and benefits

chats.George Illaszewicz: hierarchy doesn't imply that the person making the decisions is the most knowledgeable or competent

chats.Elizabeth Luckman: +1 George - and it reminds me how important it is - when we are in power - to be thoughtful about our decisions

chats.Saurabh Mishra: There should be a bottom line for success, i.e. if this happens whole team fails. in this case should have been that no one dies

chats.Elizabeth Luckman: Military is an interesting context and one in which leadership has been extensively studied for exactly that reason

chats.Adam Scalera: Many times, Hierarchy just means someone has more pieces of paper (speaking from the science fields).

chats.Natalia Podporina: "Necessary evil" is an ethic problem that can't be really implemented in organizational environment without big negative input on the whole goal

chats.Velineni Rao: Group 7 - In absence of hierarchy, flat teams might loose valuable time in making the decision as no one is responsible to make a quick decision in difficult situations

chats.Sam Ng: Coursera mentioned that managers often overestimate their ability to make high-quality decision without the input of others

chats.Nilesh Kumar: Can get inputs from all, but eventually somebody has to make a collective call and move in one direction and so hierarchy as 'necessary evil ' is required.

chats.Kamran Amini: hierarchy tends NOT to generate a wide range of information. "The more complex the task, the more likely we are to make a mistake or miss something critical"

chats.Deric Greger: Well for the military a leadership structure in combat situations, since the group has to be provided information from on person. If to many people giving orders, it could lead to deaths. The problem is many are promoted with out the real skills needed to lead and so that leads to very bad hierarchy structures in the military.

chats.Kari Keating: In the readings for this Module, we also learned that communicating a common goal/vision is among the most valuable leadership competency.

chats.Mee-Hyoe Koo: Professor -- in the context of hierarchical decision making the decision on behalf of 'organizational good' sometimes the morality and 'was it the right decision as a human being' gets questioned. How does the leader justify the 'organizational good' decision when it dilutes and undermines the 'was it an ethical decision as a human being'?

chats.Don Van Dyke: Apologies all. Technical difficulties with Canvas live sessions login has just been resolved.

chats.Darrell Kisselburgh: Communication and "buy in" on the strategy is key along with defined roles in the hierarchy.

chats.Velineni Rao: Also cultural, where leadership is more exclusive in making decision without much inclusion and participation of the team

chats.Morgan Schwenn: we can have hierarchy & inclusive decision making, but the decision still needs to be made

chats.William Rodgers: Can too many voices in the decision and concern cause no action to be taken?

chats.Alexandra Duston: Interesting, we also mentioned the military structure in our group. We also discussed the value of leadership and how a leader with a better track record in reaching the summit and expense of casualties would be a key factor is choosing which leader to join on the journey.

chats.William Rodgers: @Elizabeth...my background in military, business, coaching youth sports, and leading young Cub Scouts

chats.Brian Leung: the difficult decision the leaders need to make is risk tolerance - climbing is dangerous to begin with and everybody has different interpretation on what is the right risk tolerance...

chats.Adam Scalera: You'll learn about the Abilene Paradox in BADM 509, where a bunch of people do something because nobody wanted to speak about.

chats.Daniel Lien: Hierarchy usually doesn’t have enough “inclusiveness” in the decision making process. The younger or newer people in team are not encouraged to speak up in this culture.

chats.Geoff Masson: @ William - I agree with this, less hierarchy leads to more input which can make for slower/less decisive decisions. But maybe also more consideration of risk with more diverse viewpoints.

chats.Elizabeth Luckman: William - awesome! - and what do you think about your question - have you seen this in context?

chats.Darrell Kisselburgh: @William - most definitely.  I think a voice for each level of the hierarchy should cover the concerns for each level

chats.April Ladwig: @william —think about how many teams you may have been apart of where no decision has been made because everyone has a different view

chats.Harish Bannai: More Hierarchy would cause confusion and at time it may be demotivating. On the other hand, we can have accountability.

chats.Saif Ali Kheraj: Decision-making introduces uncertainty as well, and it is up to the leader to adopt the decision path that will reduce risk to the greatest extent possible. What a leader can do is divide his group into segments, with each segment containing a different variety of abilities that complement one another.   In this way leader can create representative from each division.

chats.Elizabeth Luckman: My experience s that it is absolutely probable for people to fail to make make decisions because of information overload - both individually and in teams.

chats.Kirk Bogle: +1 Brian. It seems like in Himalayan expeditions, lives may be acceptable externalities for reaching the summit, morbid as that is :-)

chats.Michael Thompson: In this case there would need to be at least one or two individuals who would "lead" or be at the top of the hierarchy. The experienced climbers would need to take the lead and be able to judge the condition and relative skill of the other climbers. They'd have to measure the benefit of success versus the cost of failure.

chats.Aarti Lakhani: Hierarchical organizations, while they have clear decision makers and create accountability, they can be less agile and create conflict because there is less delineation

chats.Corin Gamgort: You can use the hierachy with your own decision making as well so you do not focus on decisions/action that will not be impactful.

chats.Nicolas Ferrara: In the decentralized team, there is certainly more inclusiveness-which is a positive.  The challenge is balancing inclusiveness in our roles (which likely include a decent amount of hierarchies). This is where representative inclusiveness includes a practical solution to including everyone's ideas and experiences into the decision making process.

chats.Morgan Schwenn: Ideally before a big trip like this a leader would build trust, like in an ER or military. However, these Everest trips are often a group of strangers who hired a guide. This can create chaos. There is also a great book "in to thin air" which addresses group dynamics on these guided trips

chats.Deric Greger: Well the Holacracy structure is very interesting, which allows more decision making among the employees themselves

chats.Cynthia Abrego: Our group also discussed the balance of hierarchy and culture.  People have to feel comfortable speaking up and feeling they can also influence a better approach

chats.Venkata Komaragiri: It’s all about the trust and confidence on the leader to make the decisions for the team in high risk environments. Leaders will be more responsible in making the right decisions.

chats.Alexandra Turcios: ^ not only is it representative, it encourages ownership and increased productivity - adding to Michael’s point

chats.Jessi Tamir: I worked for a company that had a hierarchy but claimed that they believed ideas came from everywhere and that they didn't care about the hierarchy...the idea was good in theory, but what we found in practice is that they put us in these equal teams, but those teams had to present all work/decisions back to a "lead team" and the lead team made the decisions anyway despite what was recommended and it actually caused more problems than if they had just left the hierarchy in place.

chats.Aaron Alvarez: I think the hierarchal organizational method will lead to a greater vulnerability to success and failure based on the expertise on the person on the top. Think George Washington vs Custer.

chats.Natalia Podporina: In extreme situation you have to relly on experience of your leader and act fast when needed. Often there is no time for disscussions

chats.Darrell Kisselburgh: There is a great short video on YouTube that puts context to leader vs boss

chats.Fayaz Rasheed: Hierarchy has both positive and negative effects. We have to leverage the perspectives of different experts which helps leaders make a informed decision.

chats.Nikul Thakkar: Hierarchy decision making focuses on the objective but will understand there is a necessary “opportunity cost” which means they may have more leeway for safety. The flat organization will potentially have too many decision makers and won’t come to a decision soon so will lose the time to summit sooner.

chats.Rachel Nixon: Group 1 - hierarchical groups understand that some will not make the summit but accept that some will be lost in the pursuit of the goals

chats.Omeed Adham Sindy: Hierarchical is mostly needed since psychologically I believe based on personalities certain people are more likely to be leaders and certain people are likely to be followers.

chats.Velineni Rao: Did any one ever got demotivated because hierarchy included too may leaders and only few people to execute the actual work?

chats.Pamela Da Mata Lima: Thinking about climbing and having hierarchy brings to mind the communication piece, if we do not have a leader who brings inclusiveness within the decisions, it might be hard. People might not want to climb up to the top.

chats.Choon Ling Tay: From another BADM508 Contingency Theories / Approach can be a solution. Combine different structures and tools to minimize the cons.

chats.Nabil Ali: I like the comment about accountability from Harish. I think without a designated leader, factions can form. Maybe even a committee would work in this case? Instead of one singular person make the calls, we have a group of people?

chats.Deric Greger: That is very common that there are way to many leaders with not enough works.

chats.Rob Travis: Hierarchical organizations or teams are better able to keep the main goal of the exercise in focus.  Without hierarchy you are more likely to bog down in decision points that delay projects.  For better or for worse, decisions need to be made to move a team or business forward.  Sometimes the wrong choice is made and it costs negative customer experience, but through team collaboration and experience, the more likely to achieve success = reaching the summit (and living!).

chats.Elizabeth Luckman: Loida’s question goes back to this question from Suresh about the definition of success and the group values

chats.Deric Greger: That makes sense in the context of any one wanting to move up, everyone wants to be the person giving the orders than those who have to carry them out

chats.Chelsea Doman (she/her): Likewise, Loida. Was there a discussion of expectations? Did everyone expect to accomplish this personally instead of the overall accomplishment by the excursion team?

chats.Michelle Palys: The challenge with hierarchical structures is the delayed decision-making what could be inefficient, or lead to death in the climbers case.

chats.Jessi Tamir: And...to tie to real world...did the leader change the success metric after the mission? LOL.

chats.Jon Warren: Definitely agreed on that. Clear goals need to be defined from the onset.

chats.Anupama Verma: A hierarchy is important because the leader of the team would find a right mix of people with different skills to create a safe environment for the climbers. And right communications and freedom to voice should be encouraged. Even includes freely expressing your gut feeling. So finding the right balance of people, communication, skills and a sense of achieving the common goal is important

chats.Melissa Majid: I assumed that the hierarchy would be more successful since tasks would be clear. As we discussed further, it took us to viewing hierarchy as causing people on the bottom to not have the opportunity to develop this skills fully.  Also in some cultures, there are people at the “bottom” and are just resigned to be there. This was related to people who go to work just for the paycheck.

chats.Alicia Sale: Sometimes I feel like the leaders have so much attributed to them, it could have merely been the closer you got to the top the worse the conditions and some people slipped, completely out of the leaders control

chats.Christine Desousa: I think everyone on the team needs to feel supported as Loida just pointed out.  The "bottom" of the team can often times be the backbone of an organization.  But if they aren't being heard or supported, you will eventually fail.

chats.Adam Scalera: It's all people dependent. Some people are just terrible managers/leaders, example is they go with the full "Head" that we learned from Coursera, but lack all the Heart... Others it's a Country Club lounge. Every scenario is unique and a great leader in Org1 might be terrible in Org2.

chats.Nikul Thakkar: +1 - Yes, who is in the group matters in this decision as well

chats.Neil Prince: definition of success in this case will define the motivation factors of every possible scenario

chats.Elizabeth Luckman: Also - back to Prof Loyd’s point - how do we craft hierarchy that is also inclusive?

chats.Rob Totaro: What if the person that died was pushing themselves beyond their limits without communicating with the leadership

chats.Saif Ali Kheraj: We have practises for each area in our organization, and members from each practise can establish a scrum to work on a specific use case. This results in more diversity and information. This also develops an individual's skill set, which inherently encourages and motivates them.

chats.Talal Mahfouz: do you have a "win at any cost" leader or "winning is surviving" leader?

chats.Vikas Singh: Understanding each team member's personality and understanding their strengths/weaknesses is essential. Also, having a clear communication with the team on contingencies is critical for success.

chats.Michael Thompson: The leader(s) has to understand the abilities of those under them. The group may WANT to push ahead and believe that they can but in a life or death situation the leader(s) needs to be able to make those calls.

chats.Natalia Podporina: I think people confusing "boss" and "leader". If you getting ignored - you working with the boss

chats.Morgan Schwenn: reminds me of my first 14er attempt with my bf. We picked a 13 mile hike after 10 days of hiking. We hit 13k feet & I was concerned that I would struggle on the way back. My bf would have loved to summit, but we turned around b/c we agreed we would do the hike together. (Needless to say we did do another 14er on a different trip ;))

chats.Hermes Pasquez: Definitely agreed on that… different POV (Point of Views) and the a defined goal to get to the top!

chats.Jessi Tamir: LOL Or --- living in the world of marketing where our projects had one goal at onset and magically a different goal when the project was over.

chats.Adam Scalera: Since I'm in the sciences, yes, we do change our definition of success constantly after the fact and redefine the entirety of the experiment and success criteria.

chats.Rachel Nixon: people at the bottom have more people pushing them to reach the goal but not necessarily motivating the bottom level to achieve.

chats.Paul Witte: I wonder if it's a matter of hierarchy only or also authoritarian team culture--in addition to [ill-conceived] success > human life goals.

chats.April Ladwig: @Rob that is one downfall to having a hierarchy without trust. Those that did not make it probably did not feel safe to speak up or disagree with what was happening

chats.Michael Janicki: In a strong hierarchical team, if the leader is qualified, you can reach the top.  If the leader is not qualified, you can die.  In a non-hierarchical team, group decision making may not get you to the top, but you are more likely to survive.

chats.Yash Sunil Gugale: Professor Loyd, that makes me think, what about underlying unsaid goals? Maybe it may so happen that each team member might not explicitly say what their goal is, but they might have their own individual agenda. How do leaders detect/find that? And lead efficiently in that scenario?

chats.Jonathan Valladares Salazar: A person that has Ability to positively influence people and systems to have a meaningful impact and achieve important goals.

chats.Loida Valentin: A leader can also design ways for the weaker or lesser experienced to opt out and voice ‘dissent’, and/or stop ‘gracefully’ to help people save face. A leader should design ways to relieve the pressure and minimize collateral damage

chats.Deric Greger: The point is to make it as a team, but if one of the people in the group is not capable or unwilling to make it, then they will most likely be left behind

chats.Purna Nallabothula: Success with Hierarchical Model with least deaths needs a well-balanced Rational System vs Natural System in the Organization (a concept discussed in BADM 509).

chats.Nabil Ali: Would a committee help address the negatives listed? Formed by a few delegates who can represent the low ranking members?

chats.Aaron Alvarez: Great Leaders account for those negatives and push others under them and above them to focus on accounting for those negatives. Listen to your juniors. Validate others. Understand that if you know the most in the room you are in the wrong room.

chats.Saif Ali Kheraj: leaders build self-propelled high-performing teams.. It all basically comes down to having the correct framework in place that operates automatically and that each employee is self-motivated.

chats.Mee-Hyoe Koo: I think it is easier for colleagues to sabotage each other in a hierarchy-centric organization rather than non-hierarchy organizational structure.

Even with start-ups though, with increased investment funding and increasing size (eventually) -- can you honestly say that it is a flat, non-hierarchical structure? Perhaps it is just a fact of life -- and something that we cannot change or influence -- ?

chats.CA2: Zhandos Zhanserikov (eLearning): @Ahmed, you can find it here after the last live session on Thursday: https://canvas.illinois.edu/courses/16327/pages/live-sessions-and-office-hours

chats.Elizabeth Luckman: Research on both chimps and humans shows that we actually crave hierarchy. If you put a bunch of people into a room and give them a problem, they will often sort themselves into a sort of hierarchy. The challenge is overcoming those negatives that Prof Loyd highlighted

chats.Adam Scalera: I and others learned quickly at a previous company, that the Director we reported to didn't know as much as us in certain aspects. They needed employees who look up to and worship them, and couldn't be questioned no matter how wrong they were, since they were the Hierarchical Manager (definitely not a leader) and made sure everyone in the group knew it.

chats.Michael Thompson: The leader of the climbing group not only needs technical expertise and experience but also a sufficient degree of empathy and inclusivity.

chats.Aaron Alvarez: Prof Luckman I think that happens because of innate desire to avoid conflict for some and encourage efficiency. water flows through the path of least resistance.

chats.Elizabeth Luckman: Tina Fey says her leadership advice is “Higher great people and then get out of their way"

chats.Rob Totaro: @Professor Luckman - Absolutely crave hierarchy. I see it play out in our courses and small groups in we work in.

chats.Elizabeth Luckman: Aaron - yes completely agree. And a desire to avoid or take responsibility

chats.Roderick Mendoza: But even if the leader had experience or was an expert, doesn't mean they cannot make a mistake, and in a hierarchical culture, the leader's decision will be less questioned which can lead to disaster

chats.Jessi Tamir: I mentioned during our breakout that I had some friends at Zappos when they went to a no hierarchy structure. Most of them took the deal to leave...they felt that suddenly they had no career path forward. It was interesting. It would seem being your own boss or having no boss would be appealing but it also made people very uncomfortable (to Prof. Luckman's note on humans craving hierarchy)

chats.Elizabeth Luckman: Roderick - yes and learning to make mistakes well is an important leadership competency

chats.Aarti Lakhani: Interesting book - Sapiens by Yuval Noah Harari. How humans need to get to a critical mass in a group and hierarchy forms and is actually looked upon as positive and necessary

chats.Elizabeth Luckman: Jessi - Zappo’s is fascinating - so great in theory but the wholacracy thing really didn’t work out in practice

chats.Eric Shannon: my leadership role models are all personal to me. my grandfather, my pastor, and my mentor

chats.Rachel Nixon: Influencers have too much referent power, sometimes perceived as experts but not necessarily

chats.Natalia Podporina: Zappos is almost unique case. Average age of the employees is 29. At this age you still want to be "with the crowd"

chats.Aaron Alvarez: @Paul Witte - one leadership role model was a captain in the Marine corps. we were in the field for a while doing a communication exercise. at the end when we got what we needed to. He bought pizza for everyone. When I asked him why he said " that is why officers get more money. So we can better provide for those under us. Great Leader.

chats.Michael Personius: @Benjamin It depends on how much you want to be liked by the people following you

chats.Choon Ling Tay: Both referent and expert is personal bases that we can build along the career.  Reward, legitimate, coercive are positional base.

chats.Elizabeth Luckman: Another leader I admire that you would all know - Dean Brown. He has led us through the pandemic with integrity and authenticity - but also has made decisions based on his expertise that support his teams

chats.Talal Mahfouz: INFORMATIONAL POWER (Game of Thrones: "Little finger" or Lord Varys - the master of whispers)

chats.Koffi Guidi: I like the way Prof Kari categorize the power in 2 groups: Position in Personal.

chats.Deric Greger: Most leaders I have seen use their coercive power way to much. Expert power should be more powerful than it is, great example is the scientist postion.

chats.Elizabeth Luckman: Deric - agree. Coercive power also tends to be used by “fearful” leaders

chats.Aarti Lakhani: Interesting recent experience - how the absence of (personal) power but having legitimate power was used to remove personal power and create different hierarchy

chats.Kari Keating: @Talal so glad you brought that up. Informational Power is a debatable "6th" type of power that researchers have posited. Access to information can be a source of real power.

chats.Loida Valentin: I’m glad that we are also discussing the ‘dotted-line’ use cases. Even in The Godfather there was the role of The Consigliere.

chats.Vikas Singh: This is a good exercise so see what your own power perspective is.

chats.Anupama Verma: Actively pursue rewards - may not be their motivation to lead? Could it be following their heart and passion?

chats.Aaron Alvarez: Great book on leadership. - Maxwell - 360 degree leader . I give it to all of my junior leaders. Lead up, lead down, and lead across.

chats.Michael Thompson: The "Stanford Prison Experiment" is a great case study on the consequences of power.

chats.Loida Valentin: This is fascinating about the letter ‘E’ and the POV and relation to power. It makes me wonder: how many of us are using the ‘mirror’ feature for Zoom Self-View or not? ;)

chats.Sean Chen: I wonder how much "Feeling powerful " has to do with individual personality type?

chats.Jessi Tamir: @Anupama I think this means when someone feels powerful, they might be more likely to ask for a raise or promotion than someone who doesn't feel powerful - not necessarily the motivation.

chats.Chelsea Doman (she/her): On the flip side, there are several recent articles discussing why empathy is so crucial as a leader.

chats.Mee-Hyoe Koo: Sometimes, in a hierarchy-centric organization, most power is not given to the most knowledgable or the most likeable or most capable or 'with most given hierarchical power' but to someone who has been with the organization for a long time.... often, those individuals end up having the most power with staff.

chats.Morgan Schwenn: Power isn't necessarily about being a leader. Power also has to do with power over your personal & professional life

chats.Yash Sunil Gugale: Leadership shouldn't be forceful though. That leads to bitterness. No leader should try to lead in a way they would themselves hate to see in that position of decision making. I think leadership is really backwards. It's about the well-being of the people and working together rather than commanding power. Basically, don't try to be a leader. When you put the betterment of others in all efforts, you naturally come out as a leader. What does everyone think?

chats.Deric Greger: That is interesting to say that our hierarchy position limits are built in intrinsic ability to genetically recognize facial features

chats.Roderick Mendoza: In the psychological consequences of power, are there cultural differences? Are these results based on western culture?

chats.Kevin Smith: I can see how these power dynamics are crucial to fostering inclusive teams.

chats.Adam Scalera: The best managers don't have to be the smartest in the room, they need to be able to find and lead the smartest in the room. It's a crucial skill. There's also the WAIT concept "Why A I Talking?" of knowing when to speak.

chats.Anupama Verma: When we say ‘they have trouble reading emotions’ - could this be the reason they struggle with inclusiveness?

chats.Kari Keating: You all are bringing up excellent questions and ideas. Keep this discussion going with one another on the Canvas discussion assignment.

chats.Lianli Ding: This means: If a person without high position voices, he/she would be viewed as ignoring the authority, even though it may not the case.

chats.Aaron Alvarez: to someone who doesn't listen to anyone but themselves. they suffer from internal group think.

chats.LSN: Saumya 'Saum' Pallav (eLearning): Once again, click on the pop-up to join the breakout rooms. Please let me know if you have any issues in joining. Thank you!

chats.Venkata Komaragiri: Communication plays major role, leaders often ignore this when trying to deliver, not providing the context/rationale behind the decison

chats.Shahid Rameez: Less malleable to self change (you exclude yourself from change as you feel you are responsible for changing others) and tendency to not own failures

chats.Rachel Nixon: In my group we thought the leader will continue to lead based on their personal work ethic before becoming a leader.

chats.Jack Pennuto: be aware of how people experience your actions and decisions, that will override your intentions

chats.Hermes Pasquez: Our OBN for our team was Inclusiveness in order to make better decisions

chats.Kari Keating: Honesty-Humility is one of the "newest" personality traits researchers have named and examined.

chats.Michael Personius: King George III called Washington the greatest man in the world for turning down absolute power.

chats.Margie Kerber: Be mindful of how your stress impacts your teams. It can be felt.

chats.William Rodgers: Depends on the situation....emergency situation there is not time to get everyone's input.

chats.Paul Witte: holding a dog during a meeting is a good way to lower the power distance in meetings

chats.Velineni Rao: balanced focus on meeting organization goal  (making money) and at the same time aware of emotional well being of people

chats.Nikul Thakkar: We discussed how a leader with too much power will be focused on only the goal without consideration of consequences, like the 1st discussion. They will make sacrifices to make sure their goal is achieved

chats.Christine Desousa: A leader must have the emotional intelligence to understand the different personalities and people on their team

chats.Michelle Yi Alexander: This class is already therapeutic for me to better understand some of my past bosses/leaders lol

chats.Morgan Schwenn: I think people also have subconscious biases that impact what they are empathetic towards

chats.Rita Hokstad: Group 18 - we discussed how we show emotions and soft skills. Also, internal threats within an organization.

chats.Rachel Nixon: Everyday leadership should have some level of empathy which doesn't erode the efficiency.

chats.Natalia Podporina: There are so many different ways to fail and a leader that 8 minutes session will not cover it...

chats.Alexandra Turcios: Love that professor… self imposed deadlines can actually hinder motivation and long term growth

chats.Aaron Alvarez: @ William, I don't think it matters on time if done correctly. If the crisis situation happened and you didn't understand what everyones inputs should be or could be. That to me indicates a failure on getting to know those on the team adequetly before the crisis situation happened in the first place.

chats.Adam Scalera: Fantastic point Michael Thompson. Someone insecure may not want others in their group exceeding them, and they will lead that way.

chats.Nabil Ali: "Good data makes good decisions" - I think to help prevent the consequences from blindspots, a good leader asks others about their take on a certain problem. By getting the data from others on as many scenarios/outcomes as possible, the group can move forward with the best decision possible.

chats.Michael Personius: I feel like power isnt inherently good or evil, but a tool to be used and not abused.

chats.April Ladwig: 100% agree—-some people have empathy and others don’t. It is so important for a leader to have empathy. I have noticed the leaders I know that have more empathy people like working with better

chats.Loida Valentin: Develop a culture where surfacing and identifying blind spots is encouraged — making these norms help create psychological safety. This is important when the stakes are high and a high level of quality is needed.

chats.Anupama Verma: Fear of loosing the Authority and fear of being perceived as weak - some of the blindspots

chats.Koffi Guidi: I think a good leader will be the one that believe he/she is "NOT a good leader" and continuous improvement through communication, good listening is the key to handle the blind spot.

chats.Joshua Arenson: @William As a rescue specialist even when we have a plan we still listen to suggestions

chats.Rob Totaro: As a team we have to agree on what our core beliefs are. Culture will always win

chats.Nilesh Kumar: When i think of the most successful business leaders in today's context Eon Musk, Jeff Bezos,, all seems to have a bit of arrogance, but at the same time welcoming free flow of ideas and thoughts from their bigger team.

chats.Saurabh Mishra: From my exp working in Japan, Europe and US now, the efficiency is defined differently :)

chats.Deric Greger: This class is different from 509, what is this class engagement points? How are those earned?

chats.Natalia Podporina: Leaders shouldn't "read" you to know what is happening. It's your task to get disagreement to their attention

chats.Ezioma Gbujie: I agree with Dr Loyd, during my first year residency the "efficient residents" were praised to the high levels because they "finished" first and went home but checks would indicate their patients tended to get worse and moved to the ICU

chats.Adam Scalera: What I've noticed in the sciences, there's a vast difference in quality between County College and 4-year Professors, in terms of being able to lead a class to success and mentor. In the 4- year school, the career academics often have large egos due to their publications. In the 2-year schools, they often have had careers, succeeded, and want others to now succeed. Just something to think about.

chats.Kevin Smith: We need to be self aware of the influence/power we hold over others (whether intended or not) and be empathetic and supportive enough to help others recognize the power they have as a member of the team. Everyone has a voice but do they know, or believe, that their input is needed and valued? This is key for inclusiveness.

chats.Melissa Majid: Communication in our virtual world! Over communicate and actively listen were our take-aways.

chats.Jessi Tamir: Our group talked about how leaders don't always realize that when they speak first or early that they change the direction of the conversation and may shut down thoughts or conflict. For example, I had a boss who would come in and say "So here's the project we are being asked to do. We need to do this, this, this and this and we should consider this, this and this. Any questions? Can we start brainstorming?" But almost no one would talk because she already drove the entire conversation.

chats.Denise Lewin Loyd: Where are you Ruth-Ann? I hear the crickets and it makes me think of Jamaica.
